data.title: How Wheatus re-recorded Teenage Dirtbag from scratch after losing the masters
data.meta_description: Brendan Brown, lead singer of the band Wheatus, recently spent two years re-recording his hit song Teenage Dirtbag after the masters went missing. He shares what it's like to recreate a song from scratch 20 years after its original release.
data.text:
When Taylor Swift announced plans to re-record her early albums, Brendan Brown knew better than most what she was in for.

The lead singer and founder of Wheatus recently went through the very same process with his 20-year-old hit song Teenage Dirtbag.

"The journey does get a little weird," he told Day 6 with a laugh.

Like Swift, Brown and his bandmates opted to recreate the track from scratch after because they no longer had access to the masters — the original multitrack recordings — to their self-titled 2000 debut album, Wheatus.

Swift made the decision to recreate her early work in order to regain control of her back catalogue after her former record label sold the masters to her first six albums in 2019.

But while Swift's masters were ultimately purchased by an investment fund, in Brown's case, they simply went missing.

"To lose your master as an artist, it's really, really, really bad," said Brown.

"We felt compelled to recreate them so that, if for no other reason, we could own a copy. And so that they could exist again."

Starting from scratch

When Wheatus headed into the studio to re-record Teenage Dirtbag — along with the rest of the album Wheatus — in 2016, they were determined to make the new version of Teenage Dirtbag as indistinguishable as possible from the original.

"It's incredibly nerve wracking to recreate something that people already know how it goes. You know … what if you don't get it right?"

That meant recreating obscure mistakes in the original recording, like a badly-distorted snare drum artifact at the top of the chorus.

For Brown, it also meant painstakingly recreating his own vocals 20 years after the fact.

"I wasn't a very good singer when I first recorded the album," he laughed.

"Re-singing Teenage Dirtbag and having to make the sort of vocal mistakes again was definitely the most dangerous part of it because you can permanently damage your voice, you know. So I had to take a lot of breaks doing that."

Brown estimates it has taken Wheatus two years to complete the re-recording process. At this point, Brown figures he's listened to Teenage Dirtbag at least 10,000 times.

"I didn't know what I was getting myself into when we started," he said with a laugh.

But looking back, he says he'd do it all again.

"Now we have the proof that it existed once and it exists again and it's ours. So, yeah, it's totally worth it."

Brown hopes his band's efforts, along with those of stars like Swift, might encourage other artists to take steps to regain control of their master recordings.

"It would be nice if other artists were able to see by example — our example or anybody else's — that this is something that's possible, that they can take back ownership this way."

To hear Brown describe the meticulous steps he took to re-record Teenage Dirtbag from scratch, click 'Listen' above.

Written and produced by Annie Bender.
